Title: The Evolution of the Caddis Fly
BFI synopsis: “The Caddis Fly lays her eggs on the water and they sink to the bottom. The larva emerges and immediately builds itself a protective covering of wood. After passing through the “nymph” stage, its wings begin to appear. It leaves the water, and dries and expands its wings in the sun.” (Synopsis)

Title: Infant Welfare In The Bird World
BFI synopsis: Methods employed by sea birds to care for and protect their young are contrasted with those used by various land-based birds. (NFA Catalogue)
camera/photographer: Charles Head; Edgar Chance; Oliver G. Pike
Sources: The cliffs and sea of the Cornish coast are first shown followed by shots of the nests and young of the following birds; kittiwakes; guillemots; herring gull; manx shearwater; black-backed gulls; woodpecker; chiff-chaff and goldfinch.
BIF_catalogue_1926: Pictures the rearing of young by sea birds on Cornish coast, showing Kittiwake, Guillemot, Herring Gull, Manx Shearwater, and black-headed Gull; and the less successful rearing of young by land birds, including Woodpecker, Chiff-Chaff and Goldfinch.

Title: Skilled Insect Artisans
BFI synopsis: Sequences from the life cycles of the ailanthus silk moth and the red admiral butterfly. (NFA Catalogue)
camera/photographer: Charles Head; Edgar Chance; Oliver G. Pike
Comments: Ailanthus Silk Moth and the Red Admiral
Sources: The ailanthus silk moth caterpillar is shown feeding and weaving a cocoon. The moth emerges and its wings expand. The cocoon is unwound by hand and the dead pupa is revealed. The red admiral caterpillar draws the corners of a leaf together to form and make a tent; the leaf's stalk is bitten in half to make it hang downwards. The caterpillar feeds on the leaf and when full crawls to a place in the sun, suspends itself downwards, casts off its old skin and becomes a pupa; the butterfly emerges, grows to full size and takes to flight.
BIF_catalogue_1926: The Insect Artisans are the Ailanthus Silk Moth and the Red Admiral. The pictures show how these creatures spin silk and weave a cocoon, and the way in which the change from caterpillar to moth is effected.

Title: The Battle Of The Ants
BFI synopsis: INSTRUCTION. Two colonies of wood-ants in the Zoological Gardens are divided by a moat, across which a piece of timber is laid. The film shows the invasion of the right-hand colony by the rival swarm. After a fierce combat the invaders fro the left bank gain the victory, the nest of the vanquished ants is destroyed, and the Queen and Pupae are carried across to the invaders' camp. (Shotlist)
Comments: Film with this title used in 'The New Learning Experiment'
Sources: Two colonies of wood-ants in the Zoological Gardens are divided by a moat, across which a piece of timber is laid. The film shows the invasion of the right- hand colony by the rival swarm. After a fierce combat the invaders from the left bank gain the victory, the nest of the vanquished ants is destroyed, and the queen and pupae are carried across to the invaders' camp.
BIF_catalogue_1926: The history of two colonies of Ants at the Zoological Gardens: initial quarrels between individual ants from each colony lead to fierce battle and the kidnapping of the queen; but eventually peace is declared, and the two colonies join forces.

BIF_catalogue_1926: This film shows the care taken by Nature to preserve the species, by means of adapting to each other the creature and its environment. This is illustrated by reference to the habitat of the Pheasant, the Water Hen, the Tree Creeper, the Wallaby, the Monkey, the Baboon, the Swan, and the Brown Owl.

Title: Fathoms Deep Beneath The Sea
BFI synopsis: INSTRUCTIONAL. The film opens with shots of the sea-bed (118) and informative title introduce the following forms of life: the Conger (136); Octopus (189); Wrasse (205); Sea anemones (288); feeding (328); Starfish (411); John Dory (439); the Pipe-fish (473); Shrimps and Prawns acting as scavengers (550); Gur- nard (576); and Spider Crab (740); the film closes with views of the night sky (761 ft). BIF_catalogue_1926: Beneath the waves are mountains, plains and valleys full of life: here the Conger, the Octopus, and the Wrasse hunt for food; shrimps and prawns act as scavengers; sea-anemones and starfish decorate the sea-floor, and the Spider-Crab assumes protective colouring by covering its back with pebbles.

Title: The Lair of the Spider
BFI synopsis: The life cycle and activities of the garden spider. (NFA Catalogue)
Sources: Informative titles introduce shots of the male garden spider and the female. She attacks and repels another spider. The male courts her and after mating is seized by the female, bound in a silken net andeaten. The female spins and weaves her net and catches and binds a fly and a beetle. The eggs are then shown in a bag. She retires to sleep for the winter.
BIF_catalogue_1926: The female spider accepts the courtship of her timorous male lover, but afterwards seizes him, binds him in a silken net, and eats him for dinner. She is shown subsequently making her intricate and beautiful web, using it as a lure, repairing it when torn, and weaving a silk cocoon to hold her eggs.

Title: Frocks And Frills
BFI synopsis: INSTRUCTIONAL. Shows how the Turkey Cock (70) and Peacock (150) use their "frocks and frills" to attract their mates, and how the shape and colouration of the following creatures affords them excellent camouflage: Hen Pheasant (182); Viper (209); Racoons (254); Caterpillars (440); Turbot (492); Sand Dab (533); Dog-fish (599) and scallop (638 ft). BIF_catalogue_1926: In this picture an interesting light is thrown upon the use to which animals and birds put their frocks and frills, as illustrated by the Turkey Cock, the Hen Pheasant, the Viper, the Racoon, the Peacock, and various kinds of fish.

Title: Nature's Gliders
BFI synopsis: Kittiwakes, gannets, swans and other birds are seen in flight in slow motion. (NFA Catalogue)
Sources:
The following birds are shown in flight in slow-motion photography: kittiwakes
andgannets, wild swan, black-headed gull, the commonfowl and starlings.
BIF_catalogue_1926: Slow-motion photography reveals the beauty and rhythm of the sea-bird’s flight. Interesting studies are shown, demonstrating loss of activity in the domestic fowl, and the wing-action of the starling.

BIF_catalogue_1926: The movements of wild creatures, and the significance of these movements, are illustrated by reference to the following: Goat, Kangaroo, Birds, Toad, Frog, Snake, Sea Lion, Tortoise, Land-crab and Snail.

Title: The Cuckoo’s Secret
BFI synopsis: Observations of the breeding habits of the cuckoo. (NFA Catalogue)
BIF_catalogue_1926: The film shows a Cuckoo caught in the act of laying an egg in the nest of two titlarks. The egg is hatched by the foster-mother, and she and her mate feed and tend the young cuckoo, even to the detriment of their own babies.

Title: The Sea Shore
BFI synopsis: Examples of marine life to be found on the sea shore at low tide. (NFA Catalogue)
BIF_catalogue_1926: When the tide retreats, a special world of animal and plant life is left behind in the pools of the sea-shore. Crabs and Snails, Whelks and Sea-Worms, the Sea Urchin, the Sea Mouse, the Starfish and the Brittle Star are all to be found here.

Title: The Sparrow-Hawk
BFI synopsis: THE LIFE CYCLE OF THE SPARROW-HAWK SHOWING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE YOUNG, AND THE MALE PARENT HUNTING FOR FOOD (NFA Catalogue)
BIF_catalogue_1926: This fierce bird is shown, during the breeding season, hunting for food to supply the family larder, while its mate hatches the eggs and cares for the little ones. An ignorant gamekeeper shoots the male bird, and hangs it up in his larder with his other trophies.

Title: The Story Of Peter The Raven
BFI synopsis: The activities, in captivity, of a raven captured in Pembrokeshire. (NFA Catalogue)
Sources: A wild raven is captured on the Pembrokeshire cliffs and is sold to akind master. He enjoys as much liberty as he desires and gets up to some engaging tricks. The film closes with views of the Pembrokeshire coast and rooks' nests.
BIF_catalogue_1926: A wild Raven is captures on the rugged Pembrokeshire cliffs and is sold in a neighbouring town, but finds a kind master. Peter is very clever, wicked and engaging, and enjoys as much liberty and more luxury than if he had been left in his native haunts.

Title: The Story Of The Buzzard
BFI synopsis: "INSTRUCTIONAL". Nesting site and hen (72); the hide from which the film was made (104); two eggs in close-up (135); nestling (157); care and feeding of the young birds (177); brooding hen (215); feeding the nestlings - one refuses food (267); the invalid is attacked by the other nestling (355), nest morning its body is found at the back of the nest (380). Further shots show it feeding on its prey; exercising wings; disgorging pellet offur and feathers; examination of pellet in detail; the young bird trying to fly; leaving nest.
BIF_catalogue_1926: The Buzzard has its nest high up in the cliffs of a rock-bound coast, and here the young buzzards are hatched, fed, and reared. We are shown the growth and development of the healthy youngsters, and their final departure into the wide would.

Title: The Story Of The River
BFI synopsis: “This is a romantic and not a scientific film, tracing the river’s development from its origin as mist which is drawn up by the sun and dissolved again as rain, to the moment when it reaches its final goal, the sea. The many forms of life which are to be found upon the river bank are also shown.” (Synopsis)
BIF_catalogue_1926: This is a romantic and not a scientific film, tracing the river’s development from its origin as mist which is drawn up by the sun and dissolved again as rain, to the moment when it reaches its final goal, the sea. The many forms of life which are to be found upon the river bank are also shown.

Title: Tragedy Of The Sea
BFI synopsis: semi-dramatised documentary about spider crabs. (NFA Catalogue)
BIF_catalogue_1926: A spider crab of villainous disposition searches for food in the neighbourhood of a fishing boat. A fisherman’s pipe, flung overboard, attracts a crowd of finny spectators, and in the commotion the spider crab kills and devours his best friend.

Title: The Comma Butterfly
BFI synopsis: INSTRUCTIONAL. Close-up of Comma Butterfly and the markings on his wings from which its name is derived (32); a cluster of eggs (60); the young caterpillars gnaw their way out (107); a young caterpillar feeding (147); weaving a silken thread preparatory to casting its skin (165); its casts its skin, leaving it attached to the thread (226); a later stage in its development which details of its new skin (302); feeding, with details of bristles (343); selecting a suitable place for its transformation, from which it hangs, suspended by a thread (432); the skin splits, revealing the chrysalis (480); it attaches the end of this case to the thread and hangs motionless (510). The chrysalis splits and the butterfly emerges (593) and its wings unfold (688). The butterfly feeds with its proboscis on a pear (721) and on a piece of sugar (742). Its hibernating quarters (796); attempts to awaken it from its sleep when placed in a man's hand prove extremely difficult (806 ft). (Shotlist)
Sources: Close-up of Comma butterfly and the markings on its wings; a cluster of eggs; the young caterpillars gnaw their way out; a young caterpillar feeding; weaving a silken thread preparatory to casting its skin ; it casts its skin ; a later stage in its development; selecting a suitable place for its transformation, from which is hangs, suspended by a thread; the skin splits; revealing the chrysalis; it attaches the end of this case to the thread and hangs motionless. The chrysalis splits and the butterfly emerges; its wings unfold. The butterfly feeds with its proboscis on a pear and a piece of sugar; its hibernating quarters; attempts to awaken it from its sleep when placed in a man's hand prove extremely difficult
BIF_catalogue_1926: We watch the grub turn into a chrysalis, and the chrysalis develop into a butterfly. We see the crumpled wings of the newly-born butterfly expand as the blood runs into its veins, and we leave it, a miracle of metamorphosis, flitting about among the summer flowers.

Title: Nature’s Armour
BFI synopsis: “All creatures are useful food to some other creatures, but all have means of self-protection: this is illustrated by reference to the Elephant, Hippopotamus, Crocodile, Armadillo, Woodlouse, Porcupine, Hedgehog, Lizard, Chameleon, Bison and Hermit Crab.” (Synopsis)
BIF_catalogue_1926: All creatures are useful food to some other creatures, but all have means of self-protection: this is illustrated by reference to the Elephant, Hippopotamus, Crocodile, Armadillo, Woodlouse, Porcupine, Hedgehog, Lizard, Chameleon, Bison and Hermit Crab.

Title: The Labyrinth Spider
BFI synopsis: Male and female spiders courting. The female spins a cocoon; the eggs hatch and the female spider dies. (NFA Catalogue)
Sources: Informative titles introduce shots of the male and female spiders courting; the female in close-up; a rival appears and is ejected by the male who returns to caress the female. The female spins a cocoon; eggs; she weaves a protective wall around the nest. She mounts guard and catches and eats a daddy-long-legs; a visiting spider escapes; she retreats from a wasp but attacks a hover-fly and resists an attack from man. The eggs hatch and the female spider dies.
BIF_catalogue_1926: This picture presents a domestic drama: the male spider begins his courtship of the female, overthrows a rival, and succeeds in his suit. The female prepares the nursery, lays the eggs, and guards them until the young appear, but dies as soon as they are safely launched into the world.

Title: The Rook
BFI synopsis: Captain C.W.R. Knight sets up his camera to observe a rookery in a Kentish village; the rooks and their young; male birds searching for food and driving away a buzzard. (NFA Catalogue)
Sources: The rookery is in a Kentish village. The photographer climbs a tree and chooses his spot; view from the tree. The rooks and their nests and the mother bird preening her feathers whilst brooding. The youngsters in the nest, which the mother cleans. The male bird searches for food in neighbouring marshes and returns to feed his family. Apredatory buzzard descends on the rookery but is driven away by the male birds. In due course the new generation leaves the parent nest. Rooks following the plough and ridding the soil of noxious pests.
BIF_catalogue_1926: The Rookery is in a Kentish village, and the nests are built in the top-most branches of the trees. Into this high and windy world the young rooks are born, and here they are fed and cared for. A predatory Buzzard descends upon the family, but is driven away, and in due course the new generation leaves the parent nest.

Title: The Sea
BFI synopsis: “The action of the sea upon the shore and the process of erosion are cleverly illustrated; intimate pictures are given of the nests of the Common Tern, the Puffin, and the Black-Headed Gull, and the fisherman is shown reaping his harvest from the sea.” (Synopsis)
Sources: The seashore at high tide. The tide recedes revealing sea anemones, crabs, the devil crab, whelks and sea worms. Rough seas are then shown which wear away the base of the cliffs, the broken pieces of which form rock pools under the boulders ofwhich all kinds ofsea creatures breed. Acrab waylays an unsuspecting creature; shots follow of the sea mouse and sea urchin, star-fish, brittle star and hermit crab. The seaweed left on the beach is collected by a farmer for manure. The film closes with shots of the evening sky.
BIF_catalogue_1926: The action of the sea upon the shore and the process of erosion are cleverly illustrated; intimate pictures are given of the nests of the Common Tern, the Puffin, and the Black-Headed Gull, and the fisherman is shown reaping his harvest from the sea.

Title: The White Owl
BFI synopsis: A female white owl with eggs and nest. The young develop and eventually leave the nest. Shots of the owls hunting etc (NFA Catalogue)
Comments: The Barn Owl. Read about its filming here: http://www.olivergpike.info/whiteowl.html
Sources: A female white owl; with eggs and nest; little owls. The mother returns to the nest with a dead mouse. The young develop and eventually leave the nest. Their appearance frightens a thrush and sedge-warbler. One of the youngsters looks for prey and somemiceescape its clutches. In its later development it is shown stalking prey in a churchyard and hooting in the woods at night; a man v/hose sleep has been disturbed attempts to shoot it. Thefilm concludes with shots ofthe owl during the winter in the snow and during the spring.
BIF_catalogue_1926: The White Owl, always a weird and eerie creature, is shown pursuing its avocations as a fly-by-night. We see the hatching and rearing of the young, the night expeditions in search of mice and birds, and the departure of the young owls from the nest. The strange atmosphere that clings about these mysterious creatures is very subtly conveyed.

Title: Water Babies
BFI synopsis: “This film depicts the various methods of reproduction by sea creatures, and the examples shown are the Pipe Fish, Rock-pool Blenny, Butterfly Blenny, Goby, Ray, Snake, Antedon and Tubularia (a close relation of the coral-forming creatures of tropical seas).” (Synopsis)
BIF_catalogue_1926: This film depicts the various methods of reproduction by sea creatures, and the examples shown are the Pipe Fish, Rock-pool Blenny, Butterfly Blenny, Goby, Ray, Snake, Antedon and Tubularia (a close relation of the coral-forming creatures of tropical seas).

Title: Marine Parade
BFI synopsis: The methods of locomotion employed by various forms of marine life. (NFA Catalogue)
BIF_catalogue_1926: Shows the strange manner of progression of sea creatures, with reference to the Jellyfish, Paddle-worm, Sea-urchin, Orange Comb Star, Scallop, Whelk, Lobster, Crawfish, Cuttlefish, Gurnard, Shrimp and Prawn.

Title: Spring
BFI synopsis: Short on the countryside in spring. (Synopsis)
BIF_catalogue_1926: This is a successful attempt to portray upon the screen the beauty and productiveness of springtime. The setting of this idyll is one of primroses, hawthorne, and apple-blossom; the actors are colts and calves, baby rabbits and baby birds, and other humbler creatures of pond and meadow.

Title: The Diver
BFI synopsis: “The adventures of a diver in his descent to the floor of the sea, the strange creatures he encounters, and the difficulties of his re-ascent owing to carbon dioxide poisoning.” (Synopsis)
BIF_catalogue_1926: The adventures of a diver in his descent to the floor of the sea, the strange creatures he encounters, and the difficulties of his re-ascent owing to carbon dioxide poisoning.

Title: The Path Through The Wood
BFI synopsis: “This picture shows something of the romance which is to be found in the woodlands in spring and autumn. We see the Tree-pippit, the Nightingale, the Wren, the Squirrel and the Brown Owl in their leafy retreat, and watch a silent drama between a polecat and some rabbits.” (Synopsis)
BIF_catalogue_1926: This picture shows something of the romance which is to be found in the woodlands in spring and autumn. We see the Tree-pippit, the Nightingale, the Wren, the Squirrel and the Brown Owl in their leafy retreat, and watch a silent drama between a polecat and some rabbits.

Title: Where Flies Go In Winter
aka: Where Flies Go in the Winter Time
BFI synopsis: “Flies have been a plague to mankind for thousands of years. Our ignorance of their life, since only one stage of their existence is passed in the light of day, has made it difficult to combat them, but here, with the air of the cinematograph, we are enabled to see all the phases through which they pass.” (Synopsis)
BIF_catalogue_1926: Flies have been a plague to mankind for thousands of years. Our ignorance of their life, since only one stage of their existence is passed in the light of day, has made it difficult to combat them, but here, with the air of the cinematograph, we are enabled to see all the phases through which they pass.

Title: Concerning Bills

Those shown are the bullfinch (63-78); thrush (90-102); wren (103-116); egret (130-149); sacred ibis (159-178); storks and cranes (190-232); shoebill stork (244-252); spoonbill (263-276); flamingoes (284-303); cassowary (335-349); sea eagle (363-398); secretary bird (412-449); cormorant diving and swimming under water (462-495); same in slow motion (514-565); darter (582-614); Emperor penguins (620-648); penguins in the water (660-696) and standing by the shore (701-730). Sources: Informative titles introducing shots of various birds, illustrating the adaptation of their bills to their feeding habits. Those shown are the bullfinch; thrush; wren egret; sacred ibis; storks and cranes; shoebill stork; spoonbill; flamingos; cassowary; sea eagle; secretary bird; cormorant diving and swimming under water; same in slow motion; darter; emperor penguins; penguins in the water and standing by the shore.
BIF_catalogue_1926: The bills of birds are most varied in shape and wonderfully adapted to meet the requirements of their owners, as is demonstrated by the use to which are put the bills of the Snowy Egret, Sacred Ibis, Storks and Cranes, Flamingo, Cassoway, Secretary Bird, Cormorant, Darter and Penguin.

Title: Giant Snails
BFI synopsis: Snails. (NFA Catalogue)
Sources:
Sleeping snails; one awakens and emerges from its shell; a cluster of eggs;
Roman snails hibernating; one emerges. Oblong snails of Trinidad and their eggs; a young snail is hatched and crawls away; they swim and feed in water; one buries itself in mud and sleeps. The Giant Pond Snail of the Argentine under water; laying eggs; egg cluster and young snails; the young instinctively glide to water below; crawling about weeds on which they feed under water; a snail obtains fresh air through a syphon and when the lungs are full the tube is withdrawn and it falls to the bed ofthe stream; it also obtains air through surface weeds during drought and when the water has gone buries itself in the mud.
BIF_catalogue_1926: Nature’s resourcefulness in adapting creatures to their surroundings is clearly shown among snails. Here we witness the laying and hatching of eggs, development, food, and general habits of different varieties of snails, notably the Giant Pond Snail of the Argentine.

Title: Robin
BFI synopsis: “A robin makes its nest in an old box in a shed. The interesting history of the family is followed until the time when the young robins are old enough to fly. Incidentally the villain of the piece, a large cat, is foiled in its evil designs.” (Synopsis)
BIF_catalogue_1926: A robin makes its nest in an old box in a shed. The interesting history of the family is followed until the time when the young robins are old enough to fly. Incidentally the villain of the piece, a large cat, is foiled in its evil designs.

Title: The May-Fly
BFI synopsis: The life cycle of the may-fly. (NFA Catalogue)
Comments: For regent. Film Daily review, Dec 30
Sources: A Hertfordshire stream, where the may-fly abound; eggs dropped by female in flight hatch into larvae; they are stalked and eaten by passing fish. Alarva in full growth is then shown; it endeavours to burrow into the bed of the stream but is betrayed by the movement of its breathing organs and is attacked by moorhens. The pupa stage is then shown, followed by shots of ducks gobbling them up. The pupa below water, works loose from its skin and makes for the surface; in less than five seconds it changes into a beautiful fly. Other flies are eaten by fish ; one escapes to rest awhile and is snapped up by birds; the sedge-warbiers, a grasshopper and a chiff-chaff take their toll. The pupa casts off its waterproof skin and emerges a complete fly. In one day the female mates, lays her eggs, and then dies.
BIF_catalogue_1926: In all the stages of its life the Mayfly is defenceless, and its existence is one long struggle to escape its enemies. As larvae, fish find Mayflies edible; as pupae, they fall a prey to ducks; as water-flies, they are hunted by birds; and if, after two years’ struggle to survive, the complete fly emerges, it lives only for few hours.

Title: The Stickleback
BFI synopsis: The life cycle of the stickleback. (NFA Catalogue)
Comments: For Regent. Film Daily review of U.S. release, December 30
Sources: A river, a typical home of the three-spined stickleback; a colony of sticklebacks beneath the water. A male stickleback finds a suitable spot and builds a nest on the bed of the stream. He then coerces and entices females to enter and lay their eggs, whilst he mounts guard to prevent the females from eating them when laid two other females are persuaded to add to the store. The eggs are seen through a hole in the nest; the stickleback repels intruders; a newt making its way to the nest is carefully watched and finally repelled; a caddis worm is ejected. The eggs begin to show signs of life; the newt returns to the charge and is again repelled; the eggs hatch; close shot of young fish; they are kept from straying; later they swim out- side the nest watched by the male stickleback, until they are able to look after themselves.
BIF_catalogue_1926: The male stickleback is a devoted parent: he takes on all the duties of a family. He builds a nest, attracts females to lay their eggs in it, guards the eggs, keeps fresh water running over them, and finally acts as a nurse for three months until the young can fend for themselves.

Title: The Story Of Westminster Hall
BFI synopsis: This film traces the history of Westminster Hall and illustrates the salient architectural features. Shots include the order of King Richard II for a new roof (130-161); the larvae of the death watch beetle digging into its timbers (400-476); a close shot of the beetle (476-509) and the damage caused (622-661). The remainder of the film gives architectural details of reconstruction and concludes with the Opening of the Garter Hall by King George V and Queen Mary (938-999). (NFA Catalogue)

Title: The Wasp

The nest; the queen wasp at work; in each cell she deposits an egg; the egg develops into a grub. The queen searches for food and feeds the grubs; a hornet is
driven off from the food store. To avoid being mistaken for dead when they become pupae, the grubs weave silken covers; the grubs develop; the parent wasp enlarges the comb. As one comb becomes full another is added; view from below of a complete nest. The males and females mate; the remaining undeveloped larvae are slaughtered by the workers whom themselves then die. At the approach ofwinter a young queen hibernates.
BIF_catalogue_1926: We are not wont to look upon the Wasp with favour, but, nevertheless, we shall not be able to refrain from admiration as we watch the skill and care which it expends upon the work of propagation.

Title: The Story Of The Grasses

Blades of grass are protected by saw-like edges. The flower spike of the grass appears from a sheaf of leaves and expands under the sun's rays. From each spikelet appear little anthers bearing pollen; as each load of pollen is taken away another takes its place; the pollen is carried away by the wind. Feathery stigmas are connected with immature seeds which expand and catch the pollen. Filaments of the seed of the farmer's oat are shown which, falling on the ground upside down, has difficulty with its roots and perishes on a smooth surface. The wild oat fends for itself; when the seed has settled in, the life cycle of the grass begins afresh.

BIF_catalogue_1926: "The Romance of the Flowers" gives a wonderful insight into the manner in which flowers protect their pollen, and how that pollen is carried by insects and sometimes by wonderful mechanical arrangements in the flower itself to the female of the species. Title: The Plants of the Pantry

Sources: Micro-cinematography is used to show shots of the growth of mould plants. Informative titles precede the shots which are taken at 200-20,000 times normal speed. Mould is first shown on cheese; flies distribute moulds; their tracks are shown with "footprints" which "live" and germinate. Each individual spore produces a plant; inner spores wait until the outer have grown. It develops its fruit; a closer view; it ripens, turns black and finally becomes a ball of spores ready for distribution. Related spore plants do not marry but embrace on meeting. Unrelated plants marry and consummate producing a giant cell which raises a ball of spores and results in further growths which quickly germinate to form new plants.
BIF_catalogue_1926: "Plants of the Pantry" shows the amazing growth of mould in decaying food sub-siances, such as cheese; the way it propagates and spreads. The designs thus formed are remarkably beautiful.

A large piece of meat is pulled from a bucket. Some kind of insects - cockroaches or woodlice? are poured from a tin. Bucket full of fish. Mongoose eating an egg after smashing it on the ground. A big lion¹s paw pokes through the bars of its cage to grab its meat. Lions eating. Big bear called Winnie eats an orange. Billy the hornbill bounces on its perch in an aviary and then eats grapes, taking them from the mouth of his keeper. Tree kangaroo eats something whilst holding it in its paws. Distant cousin loves condensed milk but manages to spill lots when eating. Giraffe goes through contortions attempting to eat food that has been placed on the ground. Then eats food from the treetops. Keeper offers giraffe something through the bars of the cage. Long tongue comes out to lick it. Giant toads tongues pop out and grab meal worms. We see this in slow motion. Joke about the toad¹s table manners. Python striking a pigeon to knock it down - then crushes it in its coils - in slow motion. Secretary bird attacks a snake then eats it. Elephant using its trunk to take food from keeper. C/U shots of mouth and trunk. Lemurs snatch food from each other. They eat lettuce and grapes. We see how humans compare in short sequence - picking up cakes and a glass of beer. (NFA Catalogue) Animals in the zoo at feeding time. We see eland, wolf-dog, mongoose, lion, bear, hornbill, kangaroo, kinkajou, giraffe, giant toad, python, secretary bird, elephants, lemurs, and their young and, finally, a human animal, taking and devouring their meals. (Synopsis)

Title: Friendly Flies
BFI synopsis: EDUCATIONAL. The life cycles of the Hover Fly and the Drone Fly each of which is useful to man. The Hover Fly, which is similar in appearance to the bee, lays its eggs among other insects - in this case, the Black Fly which lives on the broad bean plant. When the grubs hatch, they feed on the parasitic Black flies around them (218). When the grub has reached its full growth, it becomes a cocoon (250), emerging after about a month as an adult insect (270). The Drone Fly, a cousin of the Hover Fly, prevents pools of decaying vegetation from becoming poisonous. The female lays her eggs in the mud surrounding these pools (368). The newly-hatched grubs make for the water where they eat all the floating rubbish (455). When this is all gone, the grubs burrow down into the mud at the bottom of the pool, and begin to eat that too. They get air by means of a hollow 'tail' which reaches to the surface of the water (498). If the grubs are frightened, they can contact these tubes until the danger is past (570). The grubs can swim by contracting and expanding the skin near their heads and they also have legs on which they can travel along the bottom of the pool (620). These legs enable them to get back onto the land. Here they bury themselves in the mud and turn into cocoons (703). The adult insect emerges after about 4 days (800 ft). (Shotlist)

Title: Brewster’s Magic
BFI synopsis: Hops, barley and yeast are presented in turn. (Synopsis) "INSTRUCTIONAL". How hops, barley and yeast are processed in the manufacture of beer. Credits (35). A man at a bar draws a pint of beer (49). The commentary says that hops are the most important ingredient of beer. A shot of an old root from which a cutting is taken to grow the young hops (68). A speeded-up look at the hop's growth, pushing its way through the soil (99). A close-up of the stem, showing its "claws" (106). The expansion of the leaves speeded up 25000 times (122). A look at the plant as it begins to climb and it is shown that the claws are used for gripping (167). The hop then starts to put out flowers. The flowers of the male hop are shown (195). The flowers of the female hop. Each one is a ball of scales with sticky threads to catch pollen. However, the threads wither and fall away as there is no pollen in the vicinity. The scales, though, continue to grow as a protective device for the seeds which are not there. They become covered with a sticky substance called luculin (287). A magnification of luculin. It is this that gives beer its flavour (302). Hops maturing in the hop garden (312). Shot of barley ripening in a field. Barley is the second ingredient necessary for beer (323). Barley seeds provide the malt. They are placed in water until as much as possible has been absorbed (342). They are put in layers in a warm atmosphere where they begin to put out roots. This is magnified 10000 times. The maltster turns them upside down to make sure that they do not grow too quickly. They have to change the direction of their roots. Suddenly the water supply is cut off and the roots wither and die (432). A diagram of a grain of barley which is seen to be in three parts - (1) the young plant (2) the starch store above (3) a wall between the two through which the starch cannot pass. To get at the starch the plant produces a digestive fluid which penetrates the wall and turns the starch into sugar which feeds the plant (492). There is a certain point when fluid has been produced but the sugar has not yet been used by the plant. It is at this point that the maltster kills the plant (511). The grains are mashed up in warm water. The digestive fluid continues to turn starch into sugar. This mixture is malt (533). The brewery where the malt is mixed with the hops liquid and yeast is added (550). Yeast cells under a microscope compared with a human hair (571). The yeast cells move when put into water. The cells grow in the sugary mixture and when they reach a certain size, new cells form. This is called fermentation (645). A diagrammatic explanation of how yeast breaks up sugar molecules into molecules of carbolic acid and sugar (688). The solution under the microscope. The carbolic acid forms bubbles (734). Final shot of man drinking his beer (768 ft). (Shotlist)

Title: Fit To Boil
BFI synopsis: INSTRUCTIONAL. The film shows the growth of a potato. Opening shots of a pre- sent day potato and the uneven ancestral type. An operator is shown carrying out cross-pollination between two potato plants. A diagram shows the growth of the pollen tube down the style and the fertilisation of the ovules. The berry is planted, the root and shoot develop and a small tuber is produced under- ground. This tuber i.e. the potato, stores food for the plant. In the tuber are 'eyes' or buds which sprout. Seed potatoes are put in a sprouting box which allows them to sprout upwards only. In spring, these are planted in a shallow trench a foot apart. A magnified view of one of the stem hairs shows the circulating protoplasm. The potatoes are ready for lifting in the autumn. A special plough can be used which breaks open the soil, leaving the potatoes on the surface (860 ft). (Shotlist)

Title: London Visitors
BFI synopsis: A wildlife documentary about the annual life cycle of the black-headed London seagull. The documentary uses slow-motion techniques and also shows an embryo developing inside an egg. Its characteristic black head develops naturally in the warmer months and not as a result of the London atmosphere! In spring the gulls migrate north to the Lake District; predators include pole-cats and humans collecting gull eggs for use in London restaurants. Shot of a cameraman entering a hide; the development of a gull embryo filmed inside the egg; the hatching of a chick and its growth to flying age. In autumn the gulls return south to places like Brighton Beach. Analysis of the wing movement of the gull with slow motion film. Finally, the gulls return to London.

"Their neighbours are gulls and guillemots" (470). Cliff shots with flocks of gulls (523). Flocks of guillemots on shore (541). A steep cliff face.
